title: THE ILLUSION OF SUCCESS Part 5
scripture_ref: ‘The seventy-two returned with joy and said, “Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name.” He replied, I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you. However, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”
scripture_text: The second lie that Jesus confronts is the lie that says ‘if I have power or authority, I will be happy. I need to be in control.’
devotional:
Having power and authority cannot produce authentic joy in your heart. “I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy.”

Even overcoming Satan is not the basis for real Joy. People who can trample on snakes and scorpions and overcome all the power of the enemy are very impressive; they grab the attention of others. There are some people in ministry, who because of their insecurities must always be in charge, they have a finger in every pie, they need to know about every decision and they find it hard to delegate. They give the impression of being strong, they can cope, however, these people are seldom happy. They rarely experience real joy, and any joy they do experience is usually superficial and is related to something that is external, something that makes them looks good.

Jesus learned these lessons as he was being tempted in the wilderness. Satan wanted to give him authority over all the kingdoms of the world, but Jesus refused, for He realized that real Joy is not found in the authority a person has, but in their relationship with His Father God, and their ability to submit to the will of God.

In some ways Jesus turns our whole understanding of joy upside down. We are inclined to think ‘if we are strong, fearless, macho Christians who have everything sorted and having everything sorted, will produce joy. You could interpret what Jesus is saying this way, ‘I give you the authority or the freedom to be vulnerable,’ Your ability to demonstrate God’s power over God’s enemies may be impressive, but it will never meet the deepest needs of our hearts, it will never produce lasting joy.

It is important that we don’t confuse feelings of vulnerability with being insecure in our relationship with God. No matter what we have to face, or how difficult and challenging our circumstances may be, we need to realise that our relationship with God is secure, and we are completely loved by Him. Deep, lasting joy is not found in having the ability to cope with the difficulties of life. “I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy.”

There are others who believe that if they can go through life trampling on snakes and scorpions, then they will be happy. Giving the impression of being strong and seeming to have the ability to cope will not produce joy in your heart. Often I hear my own heart say these words ‘If only.’ ‘If only I was someone else without a disability,’ or ‘if only I had a job,’ or it could be a million other things, The if only of life is an illusion, a mirage of pseudo joy.

The basis of real Joy.

Jesus said, “Do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your name is written in heaven.”

It would be very easy to see this as a throw away statement. We think yes we need to rejoice because we are saved and going to heaven. But that is not what Jesus is saying here. In the context Jesus is talking about our attitude to service. He is saying that our service must flow from our awareness of belonging; in the Hebrew mind a person’s name was far more than a title, it was his identity, it was who he was. So when Jesus says ‘rejoice that your name is written in heaven’, he is saying the thing that brings you security and joy is not the fact that you can deliver people from demons, nor is it found in having authority, nor is it found in you having the ability to cope with the pressures of life, rather your identity and joy is found in the fact that your names are written in heaven.

In ancient times, cities kept a register of their faithful citizens; so when a man died, his name was removed from the register. Those whose names were written in the register knew that they belonged. This is the bottom line, having a deep sense of belonging to God.

I have met so many Christians who are full of feelings of guilt, who are driven and exhausted as they desperately try to win Gods approval and love. They have a subliminal theology that says, ‘ If I do all the right things, and cast out demons, stand on scorpions, serve God well, be the best, then God will love me that little bit more.’ This is not how God works.

Too many corpses of faith are buried on the mission field. Many good people left to serve God without really grasping the absolute centrality of the grace of God for everyday living. Many have ended up confused, angry, lonely and deeply scarred by years of performance. They end up sharing the message of the gospel without understanding the meaning of the gospel. This was never how it was meant to be.

According to William D. Taylor in his book ‘Too Valuable to Lose’ (Pasadena: William Carey Library, 1997) ‘’Unfortunately, about 5.1% of missionaries leave the field every year. He goes on to say, Moreover, of the 5.1% of missionaries who leave the field every year, about 71% of those leave for preventable reasons.’

“What kills a soul?

Exhaustion, secret keeping, image management.

And what brings a soul back from the dead? Honesty, connection, grace.,” wrote Shauna Niequist, author of “Present Over Perfect.”

If there is one lesson we should learn from this passage it is that we should learn to belong, we should be less eager for success and become more eager to grasp the truth that we belong. We should minister to others from a posture of joy because we have a defining conviction that we belong to God.

There is nothing that makes a person more alive and more whole than the joy of knowing that they really do belong to God; this sense of belonging animates a person and fills them with infectious joy.

I believe that this joy is the pinnacle of human experience, and can be defined as a transforming revelation of divine love.
prayer: Prayer. Father is my ministry an idol?
